ticket.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types
ticket.original-body:
When you run the to_xml method on a hash and an attribute contains no data or nil, rails, by default is rendering an attribute within the xml tah :nil => true.
I seems to me that this is inconsistent when I add the option :skip_types => true to add a 'type' tag that says nil.
The other thought is adding another options which says skip_nil_attribute or something.
For now I am just doing a gsub to remove it, but that seems wrong.
all = ExamRecord.all.to_xml(:include => [:patient], :skip_types => true)
....
<patients> − <patient> <address>person st</address> <city nil="true"/> <country nil="true"/> <date-of-birth>1134-11-11</date-of-birth> <demographic-notes>sfggsdfgs</demographic-notes> <first-name>Person</first-name> <id>82</id> <last-name>Personson</last-name> <middle-name>P</middle-name> <mrn>bens123456</mrn> <phone>8989898989</phone> <phone-evening>8988989898</phone-evening> <sex>0</sex> <social-security-number>123456789</social-security-number> <state nil="true"/> ********* <zip-code nil="true"/> ********** </patient>

I seems to me that this is inconsistent when I add the option :skip_types => true to add a 'type' tag that says nil.
The other thought is adding another options which says skip_nil_attribute or something.
For now I am just doing a gsub to remove it, but that seems wrong.
all = ExamRecord.all.to_xml(:include => [:patient], :skip_types => true)

ticket.original-body-html:
When you run the to_xml method on a hash and an attribute contains no data or nil, rails, by default is rendering an attribute within the xml tah :nil => true.

I seems to me that this is inconsistent when I add the option :skip_types => true to add a 'type' tag that says nil.

The other thought is adding another options which says skip_nil_attribute or something.

For now I am just doing a gsub to remove it, but that seems wrong.

all = ExamRecord.all.to_xml(:include => [:patient], :skip_types => true)

....

−

person st

1134-11-11 sfggsdfgs Person 82 Personson P bens123456 8989898989 8988989898 0 123456789

**********

When you run the to_xml method on a hash and an attribute contains no data or nil, rails, by default is rendering an attribute within the xml tah :nil => true.

I seems to me that this is inconsistent when I add the option :skip_types => true to add a 'type' tag that says nil.

The other thought is adding another options which says skip_nil_attribute or something.

version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types
to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body:
-1 verified that this occurs in 2-3-stable
:skip_types is to remove data types while nil="true" indicates that the value is nil. The desired behavior does not match the means to do it. Perhaps passing a different option is better (:explicit_nils or something?)
This would likely break a lot of legacy code, no?
version.body-html:
-1 verified that this occurs in 2-3-stable

:skip_types is to remove data types while nil="true" indicates that the value is nil. The desired behavior does not match the means to do it. Perhaps passing a different option is better (:explicit_nils or something?)

This would likely break a lot of legacy code, no?
version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body:
I agree with Dan that skipping nils when you specify :skip_types seems to break the intention of it, which is to not include the type attribute with the class of the object. There'd also be the concern of backwards compatibility.
I'd +1 an extra option for this though, ie :skip_nil_values
version.body-html:
I agree with Dan that skipping nils when you specify :skip_types seems to break the intention of it, which is to not include the type attribute with the class of the object. There'd also be the concern of backwards compatibility.

I'd +1 an extra option for this though, ie :skip_nil_values
version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body:
-1 for the requested behaviour for skip_types. I'm with both Dan and Josh on this one.
I could add a skip_nil option to both activemodel and activesupport. Should I?
version.body-html:
-1 for the requested behaviour for skip_types. I'm with both Dan and Josh on this one.

I could add a skip_nil option to both activemodel and activesupport. Should I?
version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body: -1, verified behavior in 2-3-stable... I agree with Dan. I think that :skip_nils is a good idea Hugo, but it would probably be better as a new ticket.
version.body-html: -1, verified behavior in 2-3-stable... I agree with Dan. I think that :skip_nils is a good idea Hugo, but it would probably be better as a new ticket.
version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types
to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body: Does this mean that the ability to not include the nil=>'true' is left to the individual to do themselves? Should I submit a patch? I am for adding a skip_nils attribute as well.
version.body-html: Does this mean that the ability to not include the nil=>'true' is left to the individual to do themselves? Should I submit a patch? I am for adding a skip_nils attribute as well.
version.title: to_xml nil => true attribute should not appear when I skip types

version.body: Ticket #1480 already proposes a skip_nils attribute (including patches), but was rejected as invalid.
version.body-html: Ticket #1480 already proposes a skip_nils attribute (including patches), but was rejected as invalid.

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
